Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Enhancing Biological Science Research Opportunities at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions; July 26-28, 2012; Fullerton, CA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit.

Authentic research experiences for biochemistry and biological science majors are essential for student growth and development of technical, critical thinking, and communication skills, providing the stimulus for better student retention, graduation rates, applications to graduate school, and high quality careers. A large percentage of students receive their undergraduate training at diverse Predominantly Undergraduate Institutions (PUI); from small private liberal arts colleges to large public comprehensive universities. Therefore it is vital that we maintain and improve student research training at PUIs. While there are many successful research programs at PUIs, there are also numerous challenges in establishing and maintaining undergraduate research, including higher teaching loads for faculty at PUIs and deficiencies in personnel, infrastructure and resources. This conference will bring together, for the first time at a national level, diverse PIs to meet and discuss ideas and best practices and future prospects in building and sustaining research, crafting competitive grant proposals, integrating research into the curriculum, forging research partnerships and collaborations, and accurately assessing student research training outcomes. One product of the workshop will be a report that will inform NSF BIO and the greater scientific community of successes, needs, and future prospects for PUIs.

The workshop is planned for seventy, which includes invited participants, administrators, program directors, industrial and academic partners, students, and facilitators. A unique feature of the workshop is the inclusion of the company Knowinnovation to assist in the design, development, and facilitation of the workshop using deliberate Creative Problem Solving (CPS) methodology.

Broader Impacts.

A diverse mix of PIs will be invited from a variety of institution types, including many Assistant Professors as well as faculty from minority serving institutions, which will provide the variety of outlooks and perspective essential for exploring the problem space and finding solutions. The format will allow for early career faculty to link with mentors for advice and potential collaborations. This workshop and website will provide a continuing opportunity for PUI PIs to network with each other as well as NSF staff and other stakeholders in a way that enhances efforts in undergraduate research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
California State University, Fullerton (CSUF) hosted a seminal national workshop July 26-28th, 2012 which focused on research and educational activities at PUIs, including best practices and future prospects. Entitled "Enhancing Biological Science Research Opportunities at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs): Advancing Discovery While Training the Next Generation of Scientists", the conference included 78 participants. A smaller follow up meeting was held April 17-18th, 2013. The intellectual merit and broader impact of this proposal were naturally intertwined as enhancing research at PUIs directly benefits undergraduates, many of whom are in groups underrepresented in STEM.

The major activities included sharing best practices and working toward a vision for the future (with issues addressed including envisioning an ideal research environment and back casting to determine what resources and authority would be needed to get there; what are the barriers that need to be addressed?), Particiapants engaged in pre-conference activities via an interactive social media site. Sessions included "Buiding and Sustaining Research at a PUI. It takes a village", "Integration of Teaching and Research", and "Assessing Student Research Training Outcomes: More than a List of Publications"; breakout sessions employed the principles of deliberate Creative Problem Solving. These session identified the "anatomy" of barriers to success in research at PUIs, leading to many ideas for solutions as well as numerous and varied recommendations. The question of building and sustaining research was revisited in the context of the roles of the major stakeholders. Authentic integration of teaching and research were viewed as essential at PUIs (allowing for sustainability and scaling) to provide valuable research opportunities for students. A critical need was also identified for discipline specific scientists to engage with science educators to provide more detailed assessment and evalutation of student learning and development. The general feeling was that there would be tremendous value in planning for moare collective efforts and a national network for PUI biology. The participants felt strongly that there were several unique roles that PUIs could play with resepct to enhancing BIO research and training the next generation of scientists given that over 60% of undergraduates and 80% of minority students attend PUIs: in integration of teaching and research, interdisciplinary research training, collaborative participation in "big scence"/Big Data/Citizen Science projects, and providing bridges for students between levels of education (from community colleges to research intensive universities).

Participants also engaged in a session of the PULSE initiative and Undergraduate Research, providing the first feedback from the community about this NSF, NIH, and HHMI funded effort. Participants benefited from short talks given by NSF personnel on "Preparing Competitive Grants" and "Major Research Instrumentation Opportunities". The participants also had opportunities to network with each other and NSF personnel at a reception, banquet, and poster sessions. The group also attended an interactive panel discussion on "Research Partnerships, Collaborations, and Student Career Preparation" that featured alumni from PUIs, as well as industry and Ph.D. granting institution representatives. Participants were also encouraged to sign up for potential service as ad hoc reviewers, panelists, and/or rotating program directors--critical given how underrepresented the PUI community is in the review process.
